@NGSS_tweeps However, the SEP I was not prepared for how difficult it would be to support in remote learning has been "Analyzing and Interpreting Data". I have struggled with how to support Ss who struggle with this one -- how to help students find and describe trends and make it meaningful.
@NGSS_tweeps I definitely think "planning and conducting investigations" is the most difficult to support in remote learning, especially through the lens of equitable experiences.

But we have used everything from paper and pics, Jamboard, some use Kaminor Dochub, Google Draw, the Microsoft Whiteboard on their laptops, and some have found their own tools.
@digitaltidepool @NGSS_tweeps There are simulations that allow students to make many of the decisions in carrying out an investigation. Not the same but at least can be something.

@mrs_chemistry @NGSS_tweeps Plus, I recently added the option of making videos/audio/screencasts for using models to explain phenomena and it really opened up opportunities for kids who struggle with writing. Plus I get to hear their voices!

@mrs_chemistry @NGSS_tweeps I totally see what you mean with modelling! At the beginning of the year this was a huge issue for my 7th graders but they have grown SO much this semester! After the initial scramble for what tools to use we settled on Google slides, and/or hand drawn models.

Lent: Yet, the K-12 #NGSS (or NGSS-like standards) have been adopted in 44/50 states. These K-12 standards still cover core disciplinary knowledge and also integrate cross-cutting concepts & skills. So, our UGs are prepared more than ever for integrative content (3/5) #SICB2021
@NGSS_tweeps Planning and Carrying out investigations. Resources and safety are limited.

@NGSS_tweeps Planning & Carrying Out Investigations - also - my reasons are that when we want kids to observe and ask questions about physical materials - like in a science kit, it is a big challenge to assemble & distribute enough materials for all.

@NGSS_tweeps Planning and carrying out investigations. Getting creative by working with what is available at home takes time that teachers don't have and while utilizing simulations and demos can help, remote learning has made that hands-on piece so crucial to science a bit more challenging.

@NGSS_tweeps My thoughts are shaped by the fact that I had 200 HS chem students who self-selected fully virtual learning, w/ 45 sync and 45 async min every other day.
So my numbers, and the group of Ss I had were very different from my bldg colleagues who were temporarily virtual.

@NGSS_tweeps Definitely planning & carrying out investigations.

But also developing and using models & using mathematics/computational thinking can be hard when there isn't the ability for real time monitoring and feedback. If SS get lost, I may not know until much later

Are you an @nselascience (NSELA) member? If so, it's board voting time! Check out the candidates. I know one of them really well. (Yep, it's me!) Voting is now open! I'd be honored to be a part of this group and represent Region B! https://t.co/Gokxz9z5RS #ngsschat

@NGSS_tweeps "Carrying out investigations" - If resources are limited, this SEP might be difficult in a virtual space: setting up, recording observations, & taking measurements. An alternative could be the teacher to "carry out" based on students' plans/input & monitor/document over time.

Ling in HS #LSA2021: Morse

NGSS splits courses into three goals:

- Practices (e.g. constructing explanations)
- Crosscutting Concepts (e.g. cause and effect, systems & system models)
- Disciplinary Core Ideas: this is the part that changes course to course
Morse drilling down how linguistics fulfills the kinds of standards NGSS sets out. This is key: We have to tie our work to standards at K-12; and increasingly at higher ed, too. #LSA2021

Ling in HS #LSA2021: Morse

She also highlights the concept of SELLING a class ‚Äî she talking about fitting the curriculum to the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) standards

Linguistics is a science, lets make that obvious in our teaching of it!

@NGSS_tweeps I used to teach Life & Earth Sci. I generally think that all CCCs could be used to explain most phenomena, but the challenge is to decide which CCCs have explanatory power for this explanation. Finding the most powerful CCCs for the question is what we want Ss to be able to do.
@ccc_thinking @NGSS_tweeps @WSUPullman @SarahJFick @wsucoe CCCs are rarely used alone. They work better together

@BK3DSci @NGSS_tweeps @WSUPullman @SarahJFick @wsucoe I ªm looking for students to use the CCCs as tools to figure out what is happening, how it happens, and why it happens. They need to use several CCCs to really explore a juicy phenomenon and throughly explain it. They need to examine the phenomenon through different lenses.

@sbottasullivan @drloriandersen @philiplbell @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @Doc_AOC I think that some of this is about reframing the role of teaching and focus on student learning rather than gathering materials...teaching is about listening to kids to hear how they are learning.

@philiplbell @DrDSteele_PhD @kmgill135 @sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @Doc_AOC Until we have coherent curriculum development processes across grade bands, that will be hard to achieve.

@DrDSteele_PhD @kmgill135 @sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC Totally agree! My sense is that we don‚Äôt look across grades and bands enough as we design sequences to balance out the focus & relevancies in the range of ways needed to understand and act locally, regionally, and globally‚Äîin connected and differentiated ways.
@kmgill135 @philiplbell @sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @Doc_AOC And making those comparisons can make the learning relevant for them.

@kmgill135 @philiplbell @sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC Yep, some educators lose sight of that important nugget. I had someone say that people in the NW shouldn‚Äôt learn about hurricanes because they personally haven‚Äôt experienced them.

@philiplbell @JohnRussell82 @sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @Doc_AOC Developing curricula is not easy. It requires bringing understanding of many aspects teaching and learning together in the final product.

@JohnRussell82 @philiplbell @sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @Doc_AOC It is hard to get a handle on the unit until you have really gone through it in depth. At first glance it is hard to see the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù of what students are doing. Having the depth of understanding of the phenomenon is also an issue. So much of Ts own science learning has been rote.

@philiplbell @sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @Doc_AOC A lot of these new high-quality curriculum units take a long time to implement. Leaves little time for anything else. And they are hard to trim without reducing quality.

@sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @Doc_AOC @philiplbell Everything reflects our individualism as we use it. Our contexts are different, and how we apply the information to our lives will be different. 

Teachers need to see the impact of high-quality curricula to value it and want to use it over individually created things.

@philiplbell @sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC Very important to provide local connections, but kids also need to understand about the big world that is out there. We also need to let them see that other people/places deal with issues that can be similar or different.

@sbottasullivan @JohnRussell82 @philiplbell @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen but they also have to respond to the students in front of them which may require modification/addition of activities. They should follow the script as best they can the first time & then discuss modifications, where their input will have great value (2/2)

@sbottasullivan @JohnRussell82 @philiplbell @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen I think teacher individuality comes in when they add their own experiences to the activities and lessons. The storyline provides the framework (1 of 2)

@JohnRussell82 @philiplbell @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC Very true. Fostering the T‚Äôs willingness to live in the uncomfortable world of implementing a storyline and facilitate new instructional moves is tricky especially when they are wanting to return to the familiar comfort of past practice

@philiplbell @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC This is really interesting especially in a field like where where a number of teachers engage in field experiences.

@philiplbell @sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC We need to revisit this. Other considerations besides local relevance include what material and community resources are immediately or easily accessible within school and school community

@philiplbell @sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC An example of this is outlined in my first accepted manuscript ‚¨áÔ∏è https://t.co/hHwZ20KzvH

@JohnRussell82 @sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC I think this can be particularly powerful now because of the virtual connection out to students' homes‚Äîas it allows for a distributed investigation across places in a community. We're designing a bird unit that will likely use this crowdsourcing-of-data-collection strategy.

@philiplbell @sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC Maybe something that will come out of this, with the move of PLCs into the virtual context, is a way for teachers who have a common curricular starting point to virtually investigate the materials together to look for the local connection.

@philiplbell @sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC @ScienceEdDPS We have followed the video club model in mathematics and seen curriculum adaptation as a powerful lever in the "after" enactment lens (at least, after one teacher has tried it out and we've videotaped their lesson for investigation by other Ts).

@philiplbell @sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC I remember the Debarger et al piece in Science Education a few years ago and how it worked well (I'm thinking from the locality that it was a part of an RPP with @ScienceEdDPS) - it's interesting that a lot of curriculum adaptation is done from a "before" enactment lens (1/2)

@JohnRussell82 @sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC How can we always center that level of curricula adaptation? Or better yet, find resources and ways to bring large networks of teachers directly into curriculum development with others. There's nothing quite like being at the table authoring something that is intended for OTHERS.

@JohnRussell82 @sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC Early implementation of #NGSS here was really powerful. Our district partners counted on the autonomy & expertise of teachers to adapt (misaligned) curricula to the standards. It was hard work‚Äîbut incredibly engaging & powerful.

@philiplbell @sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC That "get a handle on the base storyline" is key, but also tricky - not a lot of our structures focus on illuminating the frameworks behind curriculum instead of just what is necessary for their enactment.

@sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC I've seen teachers take a storyline and weave powerful "side trips" & even overlaid engagement w/ "parallel phenomena." I'd like to see more experimentation like that once teachers/teams get a handle on the base storyline. Teacher expertise & creativity is part of the solution.

@sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC @philiplbell As a part of @MathforAmerica's work within science and math education, I've been lucky enough to collaboratively design what this can look like through a @CADREK12 program in mathematics. I hope that Science can develop similar structures as well.

@sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC What percentage of instructional time should be focused on the standards? During the Framework process we learned of models elsewhere in the world where standards get 70-80% of the time‚Äîleaving room for teacher expertise & local topics. I wish this was a discussion we'd have.

@sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC @philiplbell I think a natural follow-up is to understand how we can position Ts to be co-opted into curriculum adaptation processes, instead of a 'train the teacher' approach that is rife in current professional learning structures.

@sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC Curriculum units designed to be centered on community-centered investigations‚Äîwhere the science investigation & learning is accountable to goals of the community would make this a lot easier. I don't think we have far flung models of that kind of curricula (yet).

@sbottasullivan @NGSS_tweeps @OpenSciEd @NGSSchat @thinksci @KRenaeP @drloriandersen @Doc_AOC Some thoughts: 

We may have common learning goals‚Äîbut I don't think we should aim for common experiences. Curricula should be adapted to local places & communities in order to relate to local history, knowledge & interests that matter there. Teacher/team autonomy is key here.

@LisaMLove1996 @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti That‚Äôs EXACTLY where I‚Äôm at!! Thanks for calling it out. Glad I‚Äôm not alone

@SpaceyProfessor @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti Have you ever had to clean out an overstuffed, unorganized closet? In order to get it organized, everything has to be taken out and sorted through. Some things can be kept and some things must be thrown away, but it is a lot of work. That's what we're doing right now.
@SpaceyProfessor @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti It's not only valid, it is vital if we are to go forward.

@LisaMLove1996 @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti So-I‚Äôve been doing a ton of self evaluation on my place, my past and my position. And wondering if a) we can rectify the divide that is so inherent in science and b)if other educators also see these intersections. If you think this is a valid endeavor

@LisaMLove1996 @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti The experience is transformative. Now as a PhD student, and one who has done a ton of curriculum work, I‚Äôm curious how we can utilize STEM experiences to foster justice and social emotional learning. Students will emerge from this traumatized. We can‚Äôt separate that from content

@LisaMLove1996 @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti Then when I started teaching astronomy, students were curious about high altitude ballooning...so I got out of the way. They‚Äôve launched ~70 experiments to the stratosphere. They drive the entire process from designing a research question, determining trajectory, recovery

@LisaMLove1996 @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti So I‚Äôve always felt that science that was relevant and tangible to students had the capacity to unify and heal-but never had a name for it. I taught earth science for  years to students who were told they couldn‚Äôt do science.
@SpaceyProfessor @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti I'd love to hear what you have been wrestling with and what thoughts have been going through your head.
@SpaceyProfessor @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti Well, I only told you a teensy, tiny bit. There's more! LOL!
@LisaMLove1996 @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti Not at all!
@LisaMLove1996 @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti The weaponization  of language; the silent school segregated
@LisaMLove1996 @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti So, so much.
@SpaceyProfessor @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti Thanks for letting me share these things. I hope I have not overwhelmed you! LOL!

@SpaceyProfessor @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti The truth is, if an anglo child was given a test created with an NA focus, the anglo child would fail miserably. Honestly, I'd rather do well on the NA test. I honor and value indigenous cultures for their wisdom and resiliency. Mainstream has much to learn from them.
@LisaMLove1996 @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti That is so crazy and just reflects the systemic prevalence of the singular and superior perspective of language

@SpaceyProfessor @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti The tests for LD are based on Anglo-American culture. We think that is the only way to test intelligence. So, when a child doesn't do well on those tests, we think they are broken.

@SpaceyProfessor @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti Absolutely! In my M.Ed. I studied the disproportionality in Native American students being diagnosed with learning disabilities. I can't remember exactly, like 3 to 1 NA are put in Sped than white. I thought that was insane so I did some research.

Trying to maintain an engaging science class anchored on phenomenon even while on distance learning/teaching. Why does the golf ball appear to float? (No salt) @cascience #ngss #ngsschat https://t.co/7ZXT7SxBkk

@LisaMLove1996 @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti Yes! And it‚Äôs crazy how we seem as a nation so stuck. Reflecting on my teacher prep, I realize how many explicit segregationist theories were preached to me as truth. Like devaluing bilingual experience in favor of the superior language. And I worked in a system built upon that.

@LisaMLove1996 @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti I think now the work begins. We have to start with us. Our own positionality. Our bias-we all have it. We have to dig deep-especially as educators in the majority class. We have to think about our speech, our content, and well-our thinking-and how that translates to our kiddos
@SpaceyProfessor @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti I should stop there! LOL!

@SpaceyProfessor @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti That involves what you mentioned, "Restorative Justice" for  society and also for the environment. A society that harbors superiority because of the color of one's skin, or any other reason, is not ready to go forward into the future.

@SpaceyProfessor @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti Do not misunderstand me, George Floyd should never have died, I am not saying it was meant to be. I do believe there was a big message there for us. A message that said, "If you want to go forward, you have to reach back into the past and fix it."

@SpaceyProfessor @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti A lot of my non-space loving friends expressed disbelief that NASA would go through with the launch despite all of the craziness that was going on. I disagreed. In some strange twist, it all happened at the same time for a reason. Stick with me here ...

@SpaceyProfessor @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti So, last May, 2 days before Crew Dragon was to launch, the tragic death of George Floyd brought racial injustice to the forefront of everything. The launch was scratched. 3 days later, the launch happened, but things had grown even more intense ...
@SpaceyProfessor @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti I actually believe that we won't get to Mars or anywhere unless we make some social changes.

@SpaceyProfessor @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti As our technology improves with new and more advanced ways that will one day take us to another planet, our society must improve as well, or we will take our social problems with us wherever we go. That cannot be.

@SpaceyProfessor @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti Also, because I haven't really discussed these things in depth, I am open to other perspectives & input that will broaden these theories, maybe even changing them completely. I love true brainstorming when any thought can be put into the arena to add to exploration process.
@LisaMLove1996 @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti Excellent! I‚Äôve done a ton of thinking on this today as well

@SpaceyProfessor @NGSS_tweeps @DenisecWright @mwilkinson3 @JamesFalletti This is good for me, because I haven't had many opportunities to share these thoughts. I'll try to be concise and if you have more questions or comments, maybe we can chat sometime.

There does feel to me to be a ‚Äútreasure trove‚Äù of potential to facilitating cross-talk between the science research and #NGSS educator communities. Where and how do you see that being leveraged? How might collaborative work be further catalyzed?

The #NGSS elevates students doing science and thinking as scientists -
engaging with both the products and in the processes of scientific work. Most US students live in states with NGSS-informed standards. Broader Impact statements in grants value applications that support K12.

Are there conversations between the science research and science education community to collaboratively leverage real world science and the #NGSS to create powerful, useful resources for K12 students to engage with current science?

This makes me wonder: Scientists often include K12 materials as part of Broader Impacts goals for projects. What knowledge do most have about #NGSS? Are there resources to help practicing scientists envision the potential of their real world projects in supporting K12 education?

A scientist friend was working on Broader Impacts on K12 education for a grant proposal. I pointed them to some language from #NGSS - relevant DCIs and also practices, crosscutting concepts, connections to NOS and science, tech, society, and enviro. ‚ÄúWow! A treasure trove!‚Äù

@NGSS_tweeps @MudKevin Religion is a choice for adults. For children, families do not always convey that it's a choice. Religious practices (both visible ones and less visible) can affect engagement, participation, feelings of belonging, etc.
Day 45 - I would like to say that @KRScienceLady is an awesome person who has definitely helped me in understanding and using the NGSS. I truly respect her and am glad I can call her a friend.

@NGSS_tweeps @TechyBeckyYoung The term English Learners captures our students better than "non-English speakers." We avoid ESL because English is often a third or fourth language our studentsl are acquiring! Another helpful descriptor is "multilingual students."

@NGSS_tweeps @MudKevin We have many students in our classrooms whose ethnicity/culture includes a religious identity marginalized in the U.S. The most prominent example may be Islam/Muslim  but there are others. I think it's important to attend to these identities when we think about equity.

@NGSS_tweeps @MudKevin Respectfully disagree @NGSS_tweeps , your view as an adult aligned to Christianity, the idea that religion is a choice, this cannot be reflected onto all youth growing up in religious community. This makes me curious,  what resources you use to consider equity?

@NGSS_tweeps Adding:
- Students with learning needs, both physical and emotional, whole spectrum (IEP, 504).
- Trauma informed equitable practices.
- ELL and language learners. 
- Religion and family beliefs / culture. 
- Refugees, and new immigrants.
- Undocumented students.
@NGSS_tweeps https://t.co/xKxN3rImNd  Blurb about our teacher equity experiences @MTU_MiSTAR
@NGSS_tweeps I think they should be separate. Immigration status does not always equate to language acquisition. And some students that are ELs are also not immigrants.

Tonight at Interface Conf I will talk about ?s that probe students' thinking, that are intrinsically interesting, use familiar phenomena, & reveal where ideas may come from, such as the balloon probe for a particle model of matter. #NSTA #STOM #NGSS https://t.co/uFSeZSSXJL

@NGSS_tweeps I think we have to be careful when selecting phenomena that they don't all come through the lens of the instructor. It can be difficult in some circumstances, say if an instructor has to use a specific curriculum. I have plans for next year though.

@NGSS_tweeps @MTU_MiSTAR Yes, yes it is! I did some informal action research and found pretest scores in @MTU_MiSTAR units much lower for at risk Ss but post test scores almost equal to "honors" Ss.  Closing the gap for real! Just by employing good NGSS pedagogy.

@czavacki @NGSS_tweeps I like the "tapering back as they learn how to learn".  Do you find the key helps students distinguish and identify areas where they have questions?  I do, for the most part, and I really like using a key for that reason.

@KatyDornbos @NGSS_tweeps In the beginning of the year we check and leave feedback on any formative even with a key then taper back on comments later in the year when they learn how to learn.  S know how to ‚Äúplay school‚Äù more than they know how to learn. (So I guess just commentary)

@czavacki @NGSS_tweeps Are you offering this as something different than my original post, or commentary? Just wanting to understand your point here! 

I give students keys to help them self-assess - this serves as the beginning of a "feedback conversation".

@KatyDornbos @NGSS_tweeps Anything that is practice should never be graded.  They should be checked with feedback for learning. They are a conversation between the T and S and parent when put in the grade book as a formative.  Then when the summative happens there are no surprises.

I don't grade practice problems or notes, but I do check to see they're complete before Ss can take a quiz over the content, since Ss can use them on the quizzes (which are graded).

Curious how others use practice + notes to improve student learning.

Crosscutting concepts have 4 functions for teaching and learning with phenomena. 

1 - Lenses that reveal different aspects 
2 - Tools for figuring out
3 - Bridges to make connections across disciplines
4 - Rules of the game, or guides for doing science

@phenomonica @JohnRussell82 (2/2) Also be aware that the ETS PEs in MS and HS also lack CCCs (although HS-ETS1-4 does have a Systems and System Models CCC integrated into it.) #ngsschat

@phenomonica @JohnRussell82 (1/2) As @phenomonica suggests, each of the ETS DCIs should really be taught (and assessed) in a context with a PS, LS, or ESS DCI. That other DCI would then influence what CCC would be combined with the ETS DCI.  #ngsschat

One more finding that may be worth mentioning. There weren't strong differences in sentiment at the individual post level for tweets that included #NGSSchat vs. those that did not. But *people* who posted more to #NGSSchat (during or ourside of chats) were more positive abt NGSS.

Finally, through examining every public post about the NGSS, we estimated that sentiment was becoming substantially more positive over time, particularly for teachers - in contrast to what we know abt the CCSS from social media based research & public opinion polling

We wondered whether things were different for that system-wide reform. 

Using the same method as @HelenWangYying and colleague used for the CCSS, we found that sentiment about the NGSS was highly positive - in fact, sentiment was 33 times more positive for the NGSS than the CSSS

To say a word on what this was actually about, we had read a nice paper by @HelenWangYying and David Fikis that examined (among other features) the sentiment of posts about the CCSS. They found sentiment to be over-whelmingly negative. Because of our familiarity with the NGSS ...

A1: Because models are SO critical for sensemaking! I feel like I have to tell kids every year, models are NOT projects. They are just what we use to try to understand this phenomenon we're experiencing. #NGSSchat
A1: modeling allows students to work through their ideas through drafts and revisions. Allows them to show understanding and learning in an alternative way (to text)  #ngsschat
A1: Putting ideas on paper/screen about how something works for others to see, pushes student thinking. Initial models are so fun to return to and develop! #ngsschat
A1. I think this is an important practice to make student thinking visible and personal. A model is a reflection of their view of the world. #ngsschat
